Does it? If 10.7's C++11 libraries are broken, how can it?

> > Though, 10.8+ is only required for our binary distribution, 10.7 works fine if you self-compile.
>

We ran into something with Armory that sounds similar. IIRC, there was a C++11 call that was present in libc before 2.17 came out, at which point it was moved to librt. If you compiled in Ubuntu 12.04, the call would picked up in

> Does it? If 10.7's C++11 libraries are broken, how can it?

IMO its a ABI difference. We compile against 10.9's c++ libraries which probably must have ABI differences to 10.7 ones.
But better ask @theuni to be certain.

Hacky but makes sense. We do a similar thing for glibc compat configure
flag. In the case of ancient OSX it's not worth it though, OSX users seem
to have an extremely high update acceptance, no need to support a 5 year
old OS (wish we could say the same of windows)

See a detailed explanation here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8577#issuecomment-255945996

Yes, it's an abi difference in the 10.7 libc++ implementation. Unfortunately I wasn't able to narrow down all of the culprits, but I believe there are a few.
Should this be "from 0.13.0 onward"? My impression (from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8577#issuecomment-255945996 ) was that 0.13.0 already was more or less broken on 10.7?\n@theuni\n
@laanwj Yes. I just did a fresh download/run of 0.13.0 on a 10.7 vm to verify. Broken.\n

So maybe instead this should read something like: "0.13.0 was intended to work on 10.7+, but severe issues with the libc++ version on 10.7.x keep it from running reliably. 0.13.1 now requires 10.8+, and will communicate that to 10.7 users, rather than crashing unexpectedly".\n
